awd_abstract_narration:
Addressing the scientific software challenges facing the nation requires broad collaboration to foster practices, processes, and tools to improve software developer productivity and software sustainability.  Both of those are key aspects of ensuring the integrity of computational results and increasing scientific productivity. The Better Scientific Software (BSSw) Fellowship Program, launched in 2018 with support from the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), provides recognition and funding for leaders and advocates of high-quality scientific software.  This project enables NSF to collaborate in sponsorship of the BSSw Fellowship Program and participate in managing the program.  The project was piloted for one year with NSF support of one BSSw Fellow and one Honorable Mention. This award expands NSF's participation in the program to support three BSSw Fellows and three Honorable Mentions each year for two years, the same level of support provided by DOE. Each BSSw fellow will receive a stipend that can be used for various activities that promote improved scientific software, such as organizing a workshop or creating a tutorial.  All BSSw fellows and honorable mentions receive travel support to work with scientific community members and form a cohort.

NSF and DOE are leaders in advanced computing, pushing the growth of computational and data-enabled science and engineering as an essential driver of scientific and technological progress. Moreover, NSF and DOE researchers have developed a wide range of high-impact scientific software for advanced modeling, simulation, discovery, and analysis. The country faces a software crisis, however, due to disruptive changes in computer architectures and increasing complexity in next-generation computational science.  NSF partnership in sponsoring the BSSw Fellowship Program will enable a more robust approach toward pioneering the future of advanced computing ecosystems in support of American leadership in science and engineering. The BSSw Fellowship Program enhances workforce development and pathways to the NSF and DOE software communities, though nurturing a network of people who advance software practices as a fundamental aspect of increasing overall scientific productivity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of this award, six BSSw fellows were supported and accomplished the following outcomes:

 

Ritu Arora

Wayne State University

                  Arora used the fellowship to create awareness about the cause of optimizing I/O for better performance. To meet this goal, videos on the topic of optimizing I/O were created, articles/blogs were written, and code examples were refined/developed to demonstrate how to optimize I/O in scientific applications including the applications from the area of AI/machine learning. A publicly accessible GitHub repository was created for sharing the deliverables associated with the fellowship: https://github.com/ritua2/bsswfellowship.

 

Julia Lowndes

University of California, Santa Barbara

                  Lowndes' fellowship focused on supporting environmental science researchers through open source software that is shared on GitHub. Julia modernized Openscapes' open educational resources that she first built with RMarkdown by refactoring them in Quarto, and then used these updated resources to teach 6 cohorts (50 teams) of professional environmental and Earth scientists at NASA, NOAA, and the EPA.

 

Amiya Maji

Purdue University

                  Maji's work in this fellowship resulted in developing a best practices document for managing Python applications; automating installation of HPC Python packages through new tools and applications; and engaging the scientific Python community through webinars and training activities. This project has generated significant discussion among the HPC Python community regarding best practices for managing Python packages. The community discussion document for the IDEAS webinar and the feature requests on conda-env-mod Github repository support the need for further development of conda-env-mod.

 

 

Nicole Brewer

Arizona State University

                  Brewer's outcomes from this fellowship included: adapting Jupyter-based web applications into tutorials and the presentation of these tutorials to the wider community; mentoring students to expand the scope of available example applications; compiling the content and materials and sharing it with the community. The major impact of this project was in innovative teaching and learning resources. Specifically, the creation of the Jupyter4Science website serves as a comprehensive knowledge base, providing original content, tutorials, and curated resources for developing and sharing Jupyter Notebooks in scientific applications.

 

Myra Cohen

Iowa State University

Cohen's goals of this project were to build software testing modules for scientific software and provide these to the broader community packaged in different formats. The material is appropriate for DOE/NSF relevant meetings on high performance and/or bioinformatics computing. The outcomes include presentation slides, short video segments, a blog, and a webinar. Materials are open source, and freely available to the scientific community. Final deliverables included presentation slides in GitHub, videos on YouTube, a BSSw blog and an HPC Best Practices Webinar. 

 

Helen Kershaw

University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR)

Kershaw's goals for this project were: production of an online tutorial for code review; develop a website for code review; produce a webinar on code review experiences; and write a blog on the code review tutorial.

The significant results for the project include production of an online tutorial for code review and developing the code-review.org website for this, and presenting an Ideas productivity, high-performance computing best practices (HPC-BP) webinar. The results of the project have been disseminated to the community via a blog post on BSSw.io, HPC-BP webinar, and UCAR software engineering assembly open discussion event.
